prompt: <description>Part 1: Rectangular Prism with a Curved Side Create a new coordinate system with no rotation and a translation vector of (0, 0, 0.0013). This places the origin of the coordinate system at the bottom-left corner of the prism. 1. Draw a 2D sketch on face 1 of the coordinate system. 2. Create a rectangle in the sketch by drawing four lines with the following start and end points: - line 1: (0, 0) to (0.75, 0) - line 2: (0.75, 0) to (0.75, 0.375) - line 3: (0.75, 0.375) to (0, 0.375) - line 4: (0, 0.375) to (0, 0) These lines create a rectangle with a width of 0.75 units and a height of 0.375 units. 3. Scale the 2D sketch using the `sketch_scale` factor of 0.75. This will result in a smaller rectangle with a width of 0.5625 units and a height of 0.2812 units. 4. Transform the scaled 2D sketch into a 3D sketch by applying the coordinate system's euler angles (0, 0, 0) and translation vector (0, 0, 0.0013). 5. Extrude the 2D sketch into a 3D model with an extrusion depth towards the normal of 0.0833 and an extrusion depth opposite the normal of 0 units. Part 2: Curved Top Edge Create a new coordinate system with the following euler angles: (-90, 0, -90) and a translation vector of (0.75, 0.207, 0). This new coordinate system shares the same z-axis as the previous coordinate system, but is rotated such that the x-axis points upwards and the y-axis is aligned with the x-axis of the previous coordinate system. 1. Draw a 2D sketch on face 1 of the coordinate system. 2. Create the upper curve of the prism by drawing an arc and a line with the following start, mid, and end points: - arc 1: (0, 0.0013) to (0.0013, 0) to (0.0026, 0.0013) - line 1: (0.0026, 0.0013) to (0, 0.0013) 3. Draw a duplicate curve on the opposite side of the prism by creating an arc and a line with the same start, mid, and end points as the previous arc and line. 4. Scale the 2D sketch using the `sketch_scale` factor of 0.0026, which will make the height and width of the prism very small. 5. Transform the scaled 2D sketch into a 3D sketch by applying the coordinate system's euler angles (-90, 0, -90) and translation vector (0.75, 0.207, 0). 6. Extrude the 2D sketch into a 3D model with an extrusion depth towards the normal of 0 units and an extrusion depth opposite the normal of 0.75 units. This will create a very thin prism with a height of 0.75 units and a top edge that is curved and slightly angled from the bottom edge. 7. Combine the two 3D models generated from Part 1 and Part 2 using a join feature. This will create a single 3D model with a flat bottom and a slightly curved top edge. With these instructions, the junior CAD designer should be able to generate an accurate parametric CAD model with a flat bottom and a slightly curved top edge. The final model will have dimensions of 2 units in length, 1 unit in width, and 0.5 units in height.</description>
